I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based loan to India for the West Bengal Development Finance Program. The report also 
describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Supporting  West  Bengal  Development 
Finance Program, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
2.  The proposed program seeks to facilitate implementation of a comprehensive fiscal 
consolidation program in West Bengal. This will generate fiscal savings and thereby assist West 
Bengal to augment and sustain growth-enhancing development financing.2 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  West Bengal is a densely populated state, the fourth largest in India, with a population of 
over 91 million people and strategically located in eastern India bordering Bangladesh, Bhutan, 
and Nepal. West Bengal is characterized by a fair degree of vertical imbalance: the state's large 
expenditure  assignments—mostly  concentrated  in  primary  and  secondary  education,  and 
health—contrast with a generally low level of state revenues, and the gap is covered by central 
government transfers and borrowings. 
 
4.  Despite many achievements in the recent past, the deteriorating fiscal situation in West 
Bengal has put more pressure on public resources, constraining the delivery of public goods 
and services in the state. In an attempt to contain fiscal deficits, state authorities have often 
sacrificed development financing, undermining fixed capital asset formation and gross domestic 
product growth. The disregard for maintaining sound and sustainable public finances led to the 
highest deficit figures in fiscal year (FY) 2010 among all the states in India—West Bengal's 
revenue deficit amounted to 3.7% of gross state domestic product (GSDP) and the fiscal deficit 
to 4.1% of GSDP. Similarly, own-tax revenue at 4.5% of GSDP in FY2010 clearly reveals the 
lowest tax efforts among all the states in India.3 The committed expenditures of the government 
(on salaries, pensions, and interest payments) alone have almost exhausted the total revenue 
receipts  of  the  state  in  recent  years,  requiring  even  larger  borrowings  to  finance  these 
expenditures,  thereby  trapping  the  state  in  a  vicious  cycle  of  mounting  current  account 
(revenue) and fiscal deficits. The inability to rein in the fiscal deficits gradually pushed up public 
debt, which was 40% of GSDP in FY2010, the highest in the country among the general 
category states (Table 1).4 
 
5.  The weakening fiscal situation of the Government of West Bengal (GOWB) has had

negative consequences for its development agenda. In particular, the increase in debt and 
resulting debt service payments has reduced fiscal space, limited the ability of GOWB to use 
public  spending  effectively  to  meet  its  policy  priorities,  and  meant  that  fiscal  adjustment 
disproportionately  affected  capital  spending  on  economic  and  social  infrastructure.  Indeed, 
capital outlays in West Bengal have been declining from 1.2% of GSDP in FY1994 to 0.5% in 
FY2010 and are currently the lowest in India (0.7% in FY2011).5 
 
6.  These developments have not only prevented the effective use of the budget as an 
instrument  to  set  policy  priorities,  particularly  through  discretionary  spending,  but  more 
importantly have constrained both public and private investment, thus undermining economic 
growth  and  development  in  the  state.  They  have  also  seriously  hamstrung  manufacturing 
growth in the state, leading to a narrowing of the commercial tax base.

7.  Thus, the logic of the proposed program hinges on the link between creating fiscal space 
as  a  means  to  augment  and  sustain  development  financing  in  the  state  and  laying  the 
groundwork for improvements in service delivery and development expenditures. While the 
current program is focused on fiscal stabilization, a follow-on program in 2014 will focus on 
using the fiscal savings generated under the current program to finance greater efficiency in 
service delivery and improvements in livelihoods. 
 
8.  The program is consistent with the current country partnership strategy and country 
operations business plan for 2012–2014 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), which states 
that ADB will continue to provide assistance for fiscal consolidation to reinforce the central 
government’s efforts toward bridging interstate economic disparities and creating conditions for 
inclusive growth.6 
                                                
5  “In the medium to long term, the brunt is eventually borne by either new or maintenance investments in 
infrastructure, or the delivery of social services—areas where spending levels are more discretionary than the 
payment of salaries, pensions, or interest on past debt. These are precisely the areas in which the role of the 
government in promoting growth and reducing poverty is the greatest.” A. Banerjee et al. 2002. Strategy for 
Economic Reform in West Bengal. Economic and Political Weekly.  XXXVII (41). See also T. Sen et al. 2009. 
Dealing with Fiscal Constraints on Public Financing of Human Development in West Bengal. New Delhi: National 
Institute of Public Finance and Policy. This report has clearly demonstrated how the tight fiscal situation impacted 
investment in social infrastructure in West Bengal. 
6  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2009–2012. Manila; ADB. 2011. Country Operations Business 
Plan, 2012–2014. Manila.

3 
9.  The program specifies three areas to support fiscal consolidation and set state finances 
on a path consistent with a revised and sustainable medium-term fiscal framework.7 
 
(i)  Expenditure  rationalization.  Rationalization  of  public  expenditure  to  better 
support growth and human development is important. It essentially improves the 
allocative  efficiency  of  scarce  public  resources.  Medium-term  expenditure 
frameworks (MTEFs) could play an important role in strengthening budget and 
expenditure management through better utilization of fiscal resources, in line with 
GOWB’s priorities. Thus, MTEFs for the line departments, combined with a top–
down  medium-term  fiscal  framework,  are  the  prerequisites  for  effectively 
rationalizing public expenditure. However, an effective MTEF requires both a 
long-term  sector  strategy  and  a  system  of  project  appraisal  and  evaluation. 
MTEFs cannot be implemented rigorously unless supported by these two tools. 
Streamlining  procurements,  better  targeting  subsidies,8 and  better  monitoring 
salary  payments  are  also  essential  for  effective  rationalization  of  public 
expenditure. 
(ii)  Own-revenue reforms. One important prerequisite of fiscal consolidation is that 
state finances are augmented to the extent possible by own-revenue sources. 
Reforming the revenue streams is critical for augmenting own-revenue sources. 
Tax policy is only as good as the tax administration that supports it. Given 
GOWB’s  poor  revenue  efforts  compared  with  other  states  in  India,  there  is 
enough scope for improving its efficiency in tax administration. Simplified tax 
policy and procedures along with compliance-based tax systems and backed by 
risk-based tax audits can substantially improve tax compliance and thus increase 
own-revenue collection. The proposed program focuses on improving the state’s 
revenue administration based on these principles of tax management. Similar 
initiatives in other states of India suggest that strengthening tax administration 
leads to higher revenue collection by (a) reducing the administrative cost of 
collecting taxes, (b) reducing compliance costs for taxpayers, and (c) improving 
voluntary compliance. 
(iii)  Better debt management. Debt management based on factual information and 
a clear debt strategy that seeks to mobilize resources for physical and social 
investments and to achieve a clear and positive gap between returns and costs 
of borrowing has enormous potential for creating fiscal space. 
 
10.  Capacity building and institutional strengthening under the attached TA will be critical in 
eliminating the constraints characteristic of the state. Sound business processes cannot be 
implemented and maintained unless capacity development is an integral part of new initiatives. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact will be to improve development financing in the state in a sustained manner,

and the outcome will be the creation of greater fiscal space in the government budget. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
12.  An agreement between ADB and GOWB was reached on the broad areas of ADB’s 
support under the fast-disbursing policy reform program: 
(i)  Output  1:  improved  expenditure  efficiency. Moderating public expenditure 
growth, and better targeting public funds and improving their allocative efficiency 
will be achieved through two sets of reforms under the program. The first set will 
help GOWB stabilize its finances by containing short-term expenditure.9 This 
includes: (a) moderating salary growth by restricting replacement of employees 
against natural attrition and thus reducing growth in non-discretionary committed 
expenditure; (b) computerizing the salary payments to teachers at government-
aided  secondary  schools,  and  streamlining  drugs  procurement  and  stock 
management;10 and (c) moderating subsidies. The second set will help improve 
targeting of public funds and their allocative efficiency, which in turn will help 
rationalize public expenditure in the medium term. The reforms include (a) the 
establishment  of  a  fiscal  policy  and  management  unit  (FPMU)  in  GOWB's 
Finance Department that will be responsible for project appraisal and evaluation 
to help streamline and better target public expenditure; (b) formulation of long-
term sector strategies and road maps in the departments of school education, 
health,  and  public  works  that  enable  these  departments  to  prepare  rolling 
MTEFs; and (c) implementation of an integrated financial management system to 
strengthen public financial management system in the state. All these measures 
will serve to generate fiscal savings, which in turn will support and sustain a 
gradual increase in the state's capital outlays–GSDP ratio. 
(ii)  Output 2: improved revenue efforts. This entails strengthening tax policy and 
tax administration. First, rationalizing the tax brackets under the profession tax 
will help GOWB augment its own revenue. Second, revenue administration will 
be  reformed  by  (a) progressively  reducing  interface  requirements  between 
taxpayer  and  tax  officers,  (b)  improving  compliance  through  better  service 
delivery  to  the  taxpayers,  (c)  limiting  tax  leakages  in  transit  of  goods  by 
introducing barcoding of transit documents, (d) simplifying registration and tax 
payment for one-off transactions, (e) strengthening tax information management, 
(f) strengthening excise tax management, and (g) simplifying property registration 
procedures. All these measures are expected to help the state raise more funds 
from its own sources.11 
(iii)  Output 3: efficient debt management. The program will strengthen the debt 
management system in the state to ease future debt servicing spikes, and bolster 
institutional capacity to manage the stock of state debt effectively. 
 
13.  The program’s strategy is to initiate and partner key reforms for stabilizing GOWB’s 
finances in line with the directions of the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act,

5 
2010 and generate fiscal space to boost and sustain development financing (capital outlays) in 
the state. Unless GOWB achieves quick and marked improvements in its public finances, it will 
be difficult to sustain an elevated level of capital outlays. Greater investment in economic and 
social infrastructure is an important prerequisite for sustaining high growth and employment. 
Without high growth, especially manufacturing growth, the commercial tax base in the state will 
not grow commensurately with the state’s development financing needs. In other words, the 
program’s focus on higher development spending will have an indirect impact, in addition to the 
direct impact, on additional revenue mobilization, and hence on fiscal space creation, through its 
impact on growth. Moreover, once public finances are placed on a sustainable path, GOWB will 
be  in  a  strong  position  to  step  up  service  delivery  and  have  a  noticeable  impact  on  the 
livelihoods of the people of West Bengal. Finally, West Bengal being a large state, a fragile 
fiscal  situation  in West  Bengal  will  certainly  dampen  the  central  government’s  initiative  to 
consolidate combined finances of the states and the central government. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
 
14.  The current fiscal profile of the state does not permit the stepping-up of development 
financing. Both fiscal and revenue deficits remained high in FY2010, at 4.1% and 3.7% of 
GSDP, respectively, leaving very little space for development financing (capital outlays). This 
has severely hurt the state’s growth potential and private investment. Thus, the main focus of 
the program is to help the state stabilize its finances, which in turn will help it augment and 
sustain development financing. However, even with ADB’s support for reforms and consequent 
creation of additional fiscal space, it would be too ambitious for GOWB to meet the fiscal deficit 
target of 3% of GSDP (stipulated under the Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act) 
in FY2014 unless it were to further sacrifice development expenditure despite the negative 
impact on growth and development. On the other hand, the program helps the state launch the 
necessary reforms for a balanced and sustainable fiscal trajectory over the medium term, and 
for meeting the state's development financing needs. It will contribute to regaining the budget as 
the main tool to prioritize GOWB’s development objectives. Development expenditure (capital 
outlays) as a percentage of GSDP is expected to rise from 0.7% in FY2011 (revised estimates) 
to 2% by FY2014 and 2.5% by FY2016 under the program. The reforms will generate fiscal 
savings equivalent to $1.4 billion over the program period, and thereby contribute to the twin 
goals of sustainability while increasing development spending in a sustained manner. There is, 
however, a development financing gap (additional capital outlays in the reform scenario net of 
new fiscal space created under the program) of $493 million over the program period. ADB’s 
assistance will help cover 81% of the gap.12 This increase in development expenditure will 
enable West Bengal to overcome the low-level equilibrium trap (low public investment - low 
growth, especially manufacturing growth - slow expansion in the revenue base - low investment 
[development expenditure] to accommodate nondiscretionary committed expenditure).13  
 
15.  Based  on (i)  the Government  of India’s  request  and the (ii)  development financing 
requirements of the policy reform program, ADB will provide a policy-based loan of $400 million

conditions, and an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not 
made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. A two-tranche policy framework 
with equal amounts is envisaged, with the first tranche disbursed upon loan effectiveness and 
the second tranche approximately 18 months after loan effectiveness. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  The Finance Department of GOWB will be the executing agency and the secretary of the 
Finance Department will be the focal point for matters pertaining to the program. A program 
steering  committee  (to  be  chaired  by  the  secretary)  will  be  established  and  will  have 
representatives from other departments. 
 
17.  A fiscal policy and management unit (FPMU) will be set up at the Finance Department to 
assist line departments in implementing the program. It will be headed by a senior government 
official  as  the  program  director.  In  addition  to  items  under  para.  12,  the  FPMU  will  be 
responsible for: 
(i)  overall coordination and monitoring of the program, including the policy actions; 
(ii)  preparing and submitting all required reports to the program steering committee 
and ADB; and 
(iii)  helping to implement the attached TA. 
 
18.  Procurement,  advance  contracting,  and  retroactive  financing  are  not  expected.  The 
program will be implemented over 2 years. The proceeds of the loan will be disbursed in 
accordance with ADB’s simplification of disbursement procedures and related requirements for 
program  loans  (ADB.  1998.  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans. Manila). ADB will monitor program implementation through 
periodic progress reports and will field regular missions to confirm fulfillment of policy actions for 
tranche release.  
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
19.  The TA  will  strengthen  the key  institutions  responsible for  implementing reforms to 
improve fiscal management performance in the state.14 The TA outputs are: 
 
(i)  Revenue  administration.  The  TA  will  cover  (a)  implementation  of  the  tax 
information management system, especially making the payment, recovery, and 
appeal  modules  fully  operational;  (b)  implementation  of  an  excise  tax 
                                                
14  ADB is also providing assistance to West Bengal under a different TA project for establishing a public–private 
partnership cell to implement public–private partnership projects in West Bengal. ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance 
to India for Deepening Capacity Building for Mainstreaming Public–Private Partnerships. Manila (TA 7625-IND).

7 
management system, including introduction of online license renewal, product 
registration, and issue of import passes for bulk spirit for industrial and medicinal 
purposes; (c) implementing a barcode-based supply chain management system 
for liquor; and (d) strengthening of the property registration system. 
(ii)  Project appraisal and monitoring. The TA will assist in establishing an FPMU 
in the Finance Department so that rigorous medium-term fiscal programming, 
and appraisal and evaluation of government projects can be done. The TA will 
support FPMU in designing manuals and providing expert advice on processes. 
(iii)  Medium-term expenditure frameworks. Support will be provided to the line 
departments as well as to relevant officials of the Finance Department to prepare 
gender-disaggregated and poverty-focused expenditure incidence analysis and, 
drawing on these analyses, prepare relevant MTEFs based on the long-term 
sector strategies.15 This support on implementation will include expert advice and 
training. The TA will help design detailed guidelines in various areas. 
(iv)  Integrated financial management system. Technical support will be provided 
to  implement  four  modules  of  the  integrated  financial  management  system. 
These are (a) drawing and disbursement module (bill preparation, submission, 
management);  (b) employee  database;  (c)  budget–treasury  interface 
(e-allotment); and (d) government revenue receipt portal system. 
(v)  Employee  database.  The  TA  will  help  the  executing  agency  prepare  a 
comprehensive  and  gender-disaggregated  database  for  employees  and 
pensioners. 
(vi)  Debt management. In line with the weaknesses identified in debt management 
in the state, the TA will build capacity in areas of debt management, including 
developing appropriate debt management policies and strategies. 
 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $875,000, of which $700,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  executing 
agency will provide counterpart staff remuneration, office accommodation and supplies, local 
transport, and other logistical support. 
 
21.  The implementation arrangements for the TA will be aligned to those of the policy-based 
loan.  The  TA  outputs  will  be  implemented  by  the  FPMU  with  overall  supervision  and 
coordination by the program steering committee. A total of 59 person-months of consultancy 
services  (national)  will  be  required  intermittently.  The  consulting  firm  will  be  engaged  for 
recruiting the national consultants using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a 
standard  quality–cost  ratio  of  80:20.  All  consultants  will  be  recruited  in  line  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). All disbursements 
under the TA  will  be made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
22.  Several outputs of the program have technical components at their core. Stronger tax 
administration  is  expected  to  arise  from  better  taxpayer  services.  Several  information  and

8 
communication  technology-driven  initiatives  for  value-added  tax  and  other  state  taxes  are 
proposed to improve compliance. The scope of the tax information management system will be 
enlarged to incorporate several other modules, e.g., payments recovery, appeals. An excise tax 
management system will be set up. Implementation of the integrated financial management 
system  requires  sound  technical  knowledge,  as  does  the  introduction  of  project  appraisal 
techniques and the preparation of the MTEFs. Capacity building support under the program will 
assist the relevant government departments to better manage these technical operations. 
 
B.  Economic 
 
23.  The program was subject to economic analysis, the results of which demonstrate that its 
benefits considerably outweigh the costs. The key direct benefits considered are (i) reduced 
compliance costs in revenue administration (due to e-filing of tax returns, for example, and other 
information technology-based taxpayer services) leading to higher tax buoyancy; (ii) savings 
from greater efficiency and cessation of systemic leakages; (iii) targeted public expenditure on 
health and education over the medium to long run; and (iv) reduced debt service burden due to 
better management of debt and fiscal consolidation. A comparison between the baseline and 
the pro-growth reform program scenarios shows that the overall fiscal deficit is expected to be 
reduced  significantly  by  the  end  of  the  program  period  despite  higher  capital  outlays 
(development financing) (Table 2). Fiscal space created under the program, resulting both from 
revenue  augmentation  and  expenditure  rationalization,  will  contribute  to  this  outcome. 
Moreover, the debt stock–GSDP ratio will decline sharply from 37.24% in FY2012 to 30.62% in 
FY2017.16

C.  Governance 
 
24.  As part of program preparation, a governance risk assessment was conducted along the 
lines  prescribed  by  the  implementation  guidelines  of  ADB’s  Second  Governance  and 
Anticorruption Action Plan.17 This assessment was complemented by a review of areas of 
possible risk and vulnerability in state financial management. The assessment found some 
vulnerabilities that could affect the proposed program. They include risks related to (i) political 
support for and ownership of GOWB; and (ii) institutional dimensions of the proposed program 
(e.g., weak capacity in the relevant institutions). The financial assessment found several areas 
of concern: (i) lack of appraisal of investment projects and integration of capital and current

17  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was also explained to and discussed with the Government 
(Finance Department, GOWB). Consistent with its commitment to good governance, implementation of the 
program will adhere to ADB’s Anticorruption Policy.

9 
budgets, (ii) weak monitoring protocols, and (iii) lack of alignment between sector goals and 
resource allocation.18 While no major risks of mismanagement of resources at the executing 
level can be discerned, issues raised in the assessments are targeted for capacity development 
under the TA during implementation. 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
25.  The poverty reduction and social impacts of the program are positive. The support for 
augmenting and sustaining development financing will have a substantial impact on human and 
income poverty. While broadly aiming at better cost recovery and revenue mobilization by 
GOWB, the program’s special emphasis on better expenditure targeting, especially in health 
and education, is clearly geared toward protecting the poor and other vulnerable groups. The 
health indicators for women and children in the state are poor due to ineffective delivery of 
public services and lack of adequate budget allocations. This is manifested in many ways. For 
example, high maternal mortality rates in West Bengal reflect inadequate health services and 
facilities for antenatal and obstetric care. Rectifying these problems becomes all the more 
challenging if GOWB is unable to invest in economic and social infrastructure.19 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
26.  Given  the  nature  of  the  program,  all  three  safeguard  categories  (environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples) are categorized as C. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures

V.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
28.  The Government of India and GOWB have assured ADB that the implementation of the

program shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,20 safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
29.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan of $400,000,000 to India for the West Bengal Development Finance Program, from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with ADB’s London 
interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 15 years, including a grace 
period of 3 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan and program agreements presented to the Board.
